title: R Built-in Datasets
text:
Preface
Students learning R need accessible data to practice their coding skills. In theory, R provides this through its many built‑in datasets. In practice, however, working with these datasets isn’t always as simple as it sounds.
I wrote this book to close this gap between theory and reality.
R offers multiple ways to access and handle built-in datasets, and many of those approaches assume familiarity with packages, environments, and memory management—skills beginners typically haven’t developed yet. This book removes that early complexity by giving you a clear, guided path to the essential techniques for working confidently with R’s built‑in datasets.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 Contents
Working with R’s built‑in datasets can feel surprisingly challenging when you’re just getting started. This book is designed to remove that friction.
It won’t turn you into an expert overnight, but it will give you the practical skills you need to become confident and capable. Along the way, you’ll build a solid foundation that makes deeper exploration easy whenever you’re ready for it.
The approach is simple: Show, then Tell. You’ll see each idea demonstrated in real code first, and only then will we break down how and why it works.
Chapters 1 - 4
These chapters introduce the essentials of working with built‑in datasets, using examples from three popular R packages.
You’ll learn how to find, load, and explore datasets so you can start working with them immediately.
Chapter 5
This chapter presents a streamlined workflow that ties together the techniques from earlier chapters.
Think of it as a quick‑reference guide you can return to whenever you need a refresher.
Chapter 6
A bonus chapter that highlights several widely used datasets, explaining what makes them so popular and how they’re typically applied.
You’ll also get another lean workflow to support your future work.
Chapter 7
The final chapter wraps up your learning and offers suggestions for where to go next as you continue building your R skills.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.1 Getting Started
Think of this as your jump-start chapter. We’ll cover the essential definitions and walk through simple code snippets so you can start working with built-in datasets right away.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.1.1 built-in
When you think of an R package, you’re most likely interested in the functions it contains.
While functions are essential to R, be aware that many packages also contain datasets that you can use to practice R coding. Because these datasets are part of a package, they’re sometimes referred to as built-in.
The starwars dataset contained in the dplyr package is popular.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.2 Context
Imagine you are an avid Starwars fan and want to do some R coding with data about Starwars characters.
So, what should you consider when using the starwars dataset?
This chapter demonstrates and then introduces key concepts about using starwars specifically and built-in datasets in general.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.3 Install
To use a dataset, the package that contains it must be installed.
For this chapter, it’s assumed the dplyr package is installed. If it’s not run: install.packages(“dplyr”).

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.4 Load

data(starwars, package = "dplyr")
my_starwars <- starwars
ls()

[1] "my_starwars" "starwars"   


These three lines of code represent a good practice for loading and preparing to use a dataset.
1st line: requests the dataset be put into the global environment (dataset loaded into the session)
2nd line: materializes starwars in the global environment and makes a copy named my_starwars
3rd line: lists the object now in the global environment






Note



You can now make changes to my_starwars and then later, if needed, compare my_starwars to starwars to see the differences.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.5 Explore
It’s a good practice to explore the structure and contents of a dataset before using it.

2.5.1 help()

help("starwars", package = "dplyr")

starting httpd help server ... done


When you run the code above, a new window titled “R: Starwars characters” is opened that displays information about the datasets. Here’s part of what you’ll see:



2.5.2 class()
Another important function to use right away is class().

class(starwars)

[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"


The code above shows that starwars is a tibble, which is a modern version of a data frame.


2.5.3 Other functions
There are many other functions you can use to explore the structure and contents of a dataset including: dim(), str(), summary(), and head().

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.6 Use
Once a dataset is in the global environment, it can be read or updated.

base_r_starwars <- starwars[
  starwars$species %in% c("Human", "Droid"), # Filter rows
  c("name", "species")                       # Select columns
]
head(base_r_starwars)

            name species
1 Luke Skywalker   Human
2          C-3PO   Droid
3          R2-D2   Droid
4    Darth Vader   Human
5    Leia Organa   Human
6      Owen Lars   Human


The code above uses base R functions to create a new tibble named base_r_starwars, which contains information only for humans and droids.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.7 dplyr
In the context of this chapter so far, imagine that you were just learning base R functions and using them on the starwars dataset. This means there has not been a neeed to make the entire dplyr package available to the R session.
Now, image you’ve decide to start learning dplyr functions. In particular, you’d like to again select information about humans and droids from starwars, but this time using dplyr functions instead of just base R functions.






Note



Recall that earlier you verified the dplyr package is installed. (Otherwise, you would not have been able to access its starwars dataset.)



2.7.1 library()

library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


The code above runs the library() function on dplyr, making the package available to the session.


2.7.2 dplyr functions

dplyr_starwars <- starwars %>% filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid")) %>% select(name, species)
head(dplyr_starwars)

# A tibble: 6 × 2
  name           species
  <chr>          <chr>  
1 Luke Skywalker Human  
2 C-3PO          Droid  
3 R2-D2          Droid  
4 Darth Vader    Human  
5 Leia Organa    Human  
6 Owen Lars      Human  


The code above uses dplyr functions to create a new tibble named dplyr_starwars, which contains information only for humans and droids.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.8 List datasets
If you’ve found one dataset in a package that you like, it’s likely you might want to see if there are other datasets in that package.

data(package = "dplyr")

The code above shows another use for the data() function. Now data() lists the datasets available in a package.

title: 2  starwars dataset
text:
2.9 Wrap-Up

Many R packages include built-in datasets that are useful for learning and practicing R. These datasets are generally intended for instructional purposes, not for production data analysis.
Before using any dataset, it is good practice to explore its structure, variables, and documentation
In many cases, you will use library() to attach a package and make its functions available in your R session. In other situations, you may only want to load a dataset from a package into the global environment.
The data() function is the standard and recommended way to load a dataset into the global environment.
The data() function can also be used to list the datasets that are available in a package.

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.1 Getting Started
This chapter builds on the concepts introduced in the previous chapter by providing additional practice with another well-known built-in dataset.
In this chapter, we work with the diamonds dataset from the ggplot2 package. Although this dataset is commonly used to create engaging data visualizations, it’s also widely used for practicing general R coding skills.

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
Note



For brevity, some of the coding details required to access and use diamonds are not explained in detail as they were in the prior chapter.

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.2 Load
The steps below will load diamonds into the global environment.

3.2.1 Installed
Confirm ggplot2 is installed. If not, do so.


3.2.2 Access

data(diamonds, package = "ggplot2")
my_diamonds<- diamonds
ls()

[1] "diamonds"    "my_diamonds"


The code above puts diamonds into the global environment.

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.3 Explore

3.3.1 help()

help("diamonds", package = "ggplot2")

starting httpd help server ... done





3.3.2 class()
Another important function to use right away is class().

class(diamonds)

[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.4 Use
Once a dataset is in the global environment, it can be read or updated.

diamonds_subset <- diamonds[
  diamonds$cut %in% c("Fair", "Ideal"), # Filter rows
  c("cut", "price", "carat")                     # Select columns
]
head(diamonds_subset)

     cut price carat
1  Ideal   326  0.23
9   Fair   337  0.22
12 Ideal   340  0.23
14 Ideal   344  0.31
17 Ideal   348  0.30
40 Ideal   403  0.33


The code above uses base R functions to create a new tibble named diamonds_subset, which contains information only for Fair and Ideal cut diamonds.

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.5 ggplot2
So far, the diamonds dataset has been used to practice coding with base R functions, but now let’s go further to use it for some data visualization work.
Recall that earlier the data() function was used to access just the diamonds dataset, but to do plotting we’ll need to make the entire ggplot2 package available to the session.

3.5.1 library()

library(ggplot2)

The code above runs the library() function on ggplot2, making the entire package available to the session.


3.5.2 ggplot

ggplot(data = diamonds_subset, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = cut)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(
    title = "Price vs. Carat for Fair and Ideal Cut Diamonds",
    subtitle = "Data from the built-in 'diamonds' dataset",
    x = "Carat Weight",
    y = "Price (USD)",
    color = "Diamond Cut"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Fair" = "red", "Ideal" = "blue"))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









The code above uses the ggplot() function to plot data from the diamonds_subset tibble.

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.6 List datasets
See what other datasets are available in ggplot2.

data(package = "ggplot2")

title: 3  diamonds dataset
text:
3.7 Wrap-Up

You have now seen examples of packages that include a small number of built-in datasets.
The dplyr and ggplot2 packages play a central role in modern R workflows, and their built-in datasets are widely used for learning and practicing the functions they provide.
Built-in datasets from packages are also useful for practicing base R functions, not just package-specific tools.
The data() function serves two main purposes:

Loading a dataset into the global environment
Listing the datasets that are available in a package

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.1 Getting Started
You now have experience working with datasets in the dplyr and ggplot2 packages.
What you learned reflects how datasets are accessed and used in most R packages. This chapter focuses on an exception.
Specifically, you will learn about the datasets package. As its name suggests, its primary purpose is to make a wide collection of built-in datasets easily accessible.
In addition to supplying many datasets for exploration and practice, the datasets package provides the very useful data() function, which you have already seen in action.
The datasets package is part of the base R installation. R emphasizes the value of the datasets package by making it available automatically every time an R session starts.

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.2 List
If the datasets package is new to you, it’s best to first see what’s in it.v

data(package = "datasets")

The code above lists the datasets in the datasets package. The screenshot snippets below show parts of what’s displayed, including the mtcars dataset.

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.3 mtcars
mtcars is a popular dataset.
What’s shown below applies to all datasets available in the datasets package.






Note



It’s important to realize working with mtcars is different in some ways from the workflow you saw for the starwars and diamonds datasets, which are contained in add-on packages.
Here’s whats important:

The datasets package is part of the base R installation, meaning there’s no worry about needing to install it.
R makes the datasets package available each time it starts a session.

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.4 Explore
Recall, before you start using a dataset, it’s a best practice is to spend some time learning a bit about it.

4.4.1 help()

help("mtcars")

starting httpd help server ... done


When you run the code above, a new window titled “R: Motor Trend Car Road Tests” is opened. This window provides information about the structure and content of mtcars. It also shows code examples using mtcars. Here’s part of what you’ll see:



4.4.2 head()

head(mtcars)

                   mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1


The code above shows the first six rows of mtcars.


4.4.3 class()

class(mtcars)

[1] "data.frame"


The code above shows that mtcars is a traditional R data frame object, in contrast to starwars and diamonds, which are tibbles.

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.5 Load

data(mtcars, package = "datasets")
my_mtcars <- mtcars
ls()

[1] "mtcars"    "my_mtcars"


The code above loads a copy of mtcars into the global environment and makes a copy named my_mtcars.

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.6 Use
Using my_mtcars in R code is straightforward.

4.6.0.1 base R

result <- data.frame(
  name = rownames(my_mtcars)[my_mtcars$cyl == 8],
  my_mtcars[my_mtcars$cyl == 8, c("mpg", "cyl")]
)
print(result, row.names = FALSE)

                name  mpg cyl
   Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8
          Duster 360 14.3   8
          Merc 450SE 16.4   8
          Merc 450SL 17.3   8
         Merc 450SLC 15.2   8
  Cadillac Fleetwood 10.4   8
 Lincoln Continental 10.4   8
   Chrysler Imperial 14.7   8
    Dodge Challenger 15.5   8
         AMC Javelin 15.2   8
          Camaro Z28 13.3   8
    Pontiac Firebird 19.2   8
      Ford Pantera L 15.8   8
       Maserati Bora 15.0   8


The code above selects a few columns and filters for rows where the engine has 8 cylinders.


4.6.0.2 dplyr
Even though datasets in the datasets package are often used for learning base R, keep in mind their value for learning functions in many packages, such as dplyr.
First, make dplyr available to the session.

library(dplyr)

Now, you can use dplyr functions.

my_mtcars_df <- mtcars %>%
  tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "name")
result_dplyr <- my_mtcars_df %>%
  filter(cyl == 8) %>%
  select(name, mpg, cyl)
print(result_dplyr)

                  name  mpg cyl
1    Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8
2           Duster 360 14.3   8
3           Merc 450SE 16.4   8
4           Merc 450SL 17.3   8
5          Merc 450SLC 15.2   8
6   Cadillac Fleetwood 10.4   8
7  Lincoln Continental 10.4   8
8    Chrysler Imperial 14.7   8
9     Dodge Challenger 15.5   8
10         AMC Javelin 15.2   8
11          Camaro Z28 13.3   8
12    Pontiac Firebird 19.2   8
13      Ford Pantera L 15.8   8
14       Maserati Bora 15.0   8


The code above this time uses dplyr functions, creating the same results.

title: 4  datasets package
text:
4.7 Wrap-up

4.7.1 Built-in






Note



There’s variation within the R community regarding the use of the term “built-in” as it relates to discussing datasets contained in R packages.
The most strict interpretation is that only datasets contained in the datasets package should be called “built-in” since the datasets packages comes with base R and this package is automatically made available (loaded and added to the search path) each time an R session starts up. This interpretation also sometime refers to datasets contained in other packages as “package-specific” datasets.
An increasing common, more liberal, interprentation of “built-in” is that datasets contain in any R package can be referred to as “built-in” since it is literally built into the package. This book uses this more open interpretation.




4.7.2 Other key points

The datasets package is unique among R packages.
Its primary purpose is to provide datasets for learning and practicing R.
The datasets package is installed with R and is automatically available in every R session.
The datasets package provides the data() function, which can be used with any package to load a dataset into the global environment
You can also use data() to list the publicly available datasets contained in a package.

title: 5  Conclusion
text:
R’s built‑in datasets provide an ideal starting point for learning the language. They’re accessible, well‑documented, and designed to help you practice real data‑analysis skills. Throughout this book, the goal has been to give you a clear, consistent workflow for discovering these datasets, loading them, exploring their structure, and using them effectively in your own code.
The techniques you’ve learned form a practical foundation. They’re intentionally simple, reliable, and repeatable—exactly what you need when you’re building confidence with R. While there are additional ways to work with built‑in datasets, many of those alternatives require deeper knowledge of packages, environments, and memory management. Those tools can be powerful, but they also introduce nuances that sit beyond the scope of a beginner‑focused guide.
By applying the workflow presented here, you’ll be able to handle the vast majority of tasks you’re likely to encounter—easily 80% of the work you’ll want to do with R’s built‑in datasets.
Learning R is a process, and you’ve taken an important step by learning how to work with the datasets that come built into the language. These datasets are more than practice material—they’re a gateway to understanding how R thinks about data. With the foundation you’ve built, you’re ready to move confidently into the broader world of data analysis, visualization, and statistical modeling.
